Air traffic control for enterprise video.
I was the founding designer of this award-winning platform for media companies to orchestrate and deliver live TV and VOD to their consumers on every screen.


Fig 1: Launch Pad
 
Fig 2: Dashboard
 
Fig 3: Channels
 
Fig 4: Monitor and Manage video
 
Fig 5: Future Forum
 
⊡⊡⊡
Background
I joined this video tech company to help them transition their legacy hardware products to modern, cloud-native software, and in the process, solve a growing problem. They had over 50 different product user interfaces in their portfolio with non-intuitive workflows that mostly looked terrible. The UIs were inconsistent with each other, bound by no ecosystem and often overlapped in functionality—the cumulative effect of many product initiatives and acquisitions with various, questionable design standards.
Before—50+ products with no ecosystem. Non-intuitive, unattractive and inconsistent UIs
 
Approach & Process
In a redesign it's counterproductive to fixate on the legacy product. Instead, I take a step back to look at the market and users to gain an understanding of context. This up-front investment is crucial as a starting point to formulate a design strategy driven by purpose. Good design flows from good discovery and research. It's the first, crucial step in a software design process.

Read about my process (2 min read)
 
Discover
In the past, my employer's Product Managers would typically add every feature request to their products, exposing them to thousands of other users. This approach inevitably resulted in "death by a thousand cuts" and code-bloat which further hampered agility. The lack of probing discovery led to a dysfunctional dynamic, and it needed to change before the product design could improve. So, one of my first tasks was to evangelize the discovery process and change minds of at my employer. In effect, I pursued an internal "road show" by presenting to Management, Engineering and other stake holders.

My cyclical discovery consisted of a combination of internal interviews, competitor analysis, customer visits and analysis of legacy usage data. For onsite visits, I arrived with a simple plan: First, I asked a handful of broad questions, and listened attentively. Second, I passively observed users in their work environments. My direct exposure revealed something quite different from what previous assumptions. Users were paralyzed with a maze of complexity in the products. And the disorganized UI was scaring them away to the competition.

Fig 6: Customer visits
 
Fig 7: Customer comments
We spend significant resources training our employees to use your products due to an unreasonably high learning curve.
—CUSTOMER A
It's extremely time-consuming to install and upgrade your products. A dozen confusing applications, unmanaged dependencies and buggy installation procedures.
—CUSTOMER B


Define
With a plethora of useful research documented in Confluence, I collaborated with my managers to interpret it and formulate a product design plan. Naturally, this involved a lot of trial-and-error, so we quickly presented ideas on the white-board and captured them to a photo stream for subsequent review and discussion. Then, we filtered the best from the rest, and reached consensus to proceed.

Fig 7: White-boarding
 
I gave more structure to our concepts by developing semi-functional wireframes and umbrella schematics. These began to solidify the platform structure, workflows, taxonomy and terminology, and it would be the springboard for an interaction framework.

Fig 8: Definition—platform structure, taxonomy and labeling
 
Design
It's exciting see ideas take shape in the form of high-definition designs, but particularly on a platform of ambitious scope, there's more than aesthetics to deliver in this stage. It begins with a well-crafted interaction style guide, including behaviors comprised of custom components (Javascript) and look-and-feel elements comprised of stylistic classes (CSS) derived from the company brand. The result should support usability standards, incorporate the thought and planning invested in discovery and definition, express the company's personality and help maintain user experience continuity throughout every interaction in a large-scale, multi-app platform. It should also mean we don't need to reinvent the wheel every time a similar user interaction is needed on subsequent features.

My style guide delivered clear documentation and client-tested front-end code customized specifically for the current needs and growth expectations of our product—VOS.

The design deliverables were published as styles, components, patterns and lastly, a semi-functional high-definition prototype to an internal Web portal (UXHub) with supporting code delivered in a version-controlled repository and reusable components stored in an Artifactory. The code included helpful comments, references to Confluence docs, and finally, epic JIRA tickets assigned to Scrum masters for task-delegation to individual developers. It made for a well-organized hand-off to the Engineering group to execute back-end integration, API development as well as detailing acceptance criteria for later quality assurance testing.
Fig 7: UXHub—Internal Style Guide

 


 
Develop
A powerful, simple and delightful User Experience framed with a beautiful UI is still just academic until actually developed to work, perform at scale and be extensibe. To that end, some of my first and most important users to please are the developers. My deliverables to them need to be thorough, organized and even exciting in order to motivate them to work many long hours toward our design goals. To assist them in their work, my team's deliverables also include significant UI development as described above in the Design stage, including browser and client unit-testing. The up-front UI development allows back-end programmers to focus on the heavy-lifting of micro-service engineering, API development and integration. We do our job, so they can do theirs. During development, I'm available to answer questions, clarify direction, provide detailed pseudo logic and offer insight on corner cases.

Fig 8: Prototype code tested and ready for Production integration
 
Deploy
To a designer, Production deployment is both fulfilling and nerve-racking. But despite conventional wisdom—that a designer's job is done at this moment—the journey has only completed its first cycle. In fact, deployment is when it's to time for a designer to discover again—this time to learn how the product performs in the real world and repeat the process. Whether it's myself, a member of my team or a torch passed to another team to iterate, this cycle is as important as the seminal design itself.

With VOS a fundamental principle I stipulated in the deployment strategy was that software design is never done. Users expect frequent updates, bug fixes and eventually, substantial upgrades. Continuous deployment is a hallmark of good product design.

The information garnered to evaluate the product is crucial, and it comes from two categorical sources: usage data and customer feedback.

Many 3rd parties offer great tools for usage data from impressions, clicks, workflow funnels to video captures, and it's essential to integrate one or more into the deployment templates and review periodically.

Customer feedback comes from many sources, including Sales Reps, trade shows, arranged meetings and, in the case of VOS, a customer Community Forum. The goal is not to solicit feature requests, but rather to listen and incorporate key customer goals into a product roadmap, so we, the architects can design the product for our customer and not the other way around. This approach is a win-win where business goals and customer needs align.

 
Conclusion
I used virtually every bit of my past experience, skills and improvisation, to help conceive and bring the VOS platform to life. It was a daunting task at the outset. But a rigorous, creative approach and daily diligence has paid off in the form of industry recognition and, most importantly, engaged, paying customers. The evolution continues...
My roles on this project
Design Leadership and Evangelism
Customer Research
User Experience Design
User Interface Design
Prototype Development
UI Engineering Team Management
Quality Assurance
Strategy and Product Roadmap
Product Performance Evaluation
